Sidhant,

I'm not sure if this is exactly what you want, but I have some code  
that parallelizes the neural network evaluations in Ken's rtNEAT  
implementation. I basically wrap rtNEAT with python and split it into  
a single server farming out jobs over RPC to some number of clients.  
The code isn't particularly elegant (i.e. it requires that the  
clients and server have a shared disk space), but I can probably  
clean it up enough for it to be usable if you're interested.

PS: One other caveat: the code was designed to be run over a fairly  
large number of nodes (200+), so for the case where you're  
parallelizing over, e.g., multiple cores on a single computer, you  
might be better off taking up Colin's offer instead.

-- Joe

On Sep 20, 2006, at 6:43 PM, Colin Green wrote:

> There was a discussion around the new year I think regarding the
> different parallel computing models, e.g. I prefer the island model
> where each node runs NEAT pretty much independently of the other nodes
> but with an occasional passing around of the best genomes between
> nodes/islands. I haven't got around to doing anythin gliek this yet  
> though.
>
> What I will be doing fairly soon is creating a multi-threaded  
> version of
> SharpNEAT to utilize multi-core CPU's. I thought about it and I  
> think it
> will be easy to do - an evening or two say. Anyway I just put an order
> in for a new dual core PC so that should be an incentive :)
>
> Colin.
